As a rule, in my scheme, when black moves the c pawn, I have to move mine, so I can counter Qb6 with Qc2 or Qb3. Period. :-)
Strange movement, but it is seeking for an early e5 without fearing the queen's exchange. It makes sense.
I overlooked Nf3 in order to contest the center. My mistake.
this way I thought that the pressure against e5 will compensate the bishop's inactivity. If black goes f6, it opens the way for a future Qh5+, once more conditions are met.

Defending e4. I'm not blocking any bishop with this move, but it is to be acknowledged that if my dsb were in e3 I'll stay better.

I calculated that if a4 was played, Bxf7+, Kd8, Qe6, but I was unsure about Nb6, then, attacking the queen. The escape is Qxe5, so it's all ok. But I overlooked the simple...

No more risks. The game was slightly out of control, so better to be wise.
Black attacks, by his own right. Well done.
Zen retreat. Often a best stategy.
Occupying a good diagonal. Black is frankly better, but it is not easy to materialize his positional advantage.
